title: Newcastle leader grills Government over funding for the region following Brexit - Chronicle Live
text:
Newcastle leader grills Government over funding for the region following Brexit 12:02, 10 Jul 2016 Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes has sought assurances following the country's decision to pull out of the European Union Shares Get daily news by email Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes 
Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes held face to face EU funding talks with communities Secretary Greg Clark as the region seeks assurances of life after Brexit. 
Mr Forbes , leader of the Labour group on the Local Government Association, discussed the threat to devolution alongside talks on the future of council business rates. 
Hundreds of millions of pounds in EU regeneration funds had being promised to council leaders in exchange for setting up a new combined authority with an elected mayor, but since the referendum outcome last month city leaders have frozen devolution talks until more funding assurances are given. 
The agreement guarantees £30m a year for the region to spend – in addition to being given control of a £3.4bn pool of investment cash. 
The North East would also get new powers covering employment and skills, transport and planning and business activity – all intended to drive economic growth. 
Mr Forbes told the Secretary of State that the government had duty to stand by its promise, and that the North East would expect to be compensated in order to act on its job creation ambitions. 
Mr Forbes said: “The seven council leaders on the combined authority have incredibly ambitious plans to transform the North East with more and better jobs. One way we wanted to build on those plans was with greater control over European development funds. 
“Brexit potentially puts that ambition at risk, and we find ourselves in the unacceptable situation where the threat to jobs is increased because we have a government which seems reluctant to give even short term assurances of funds up to 2020, let alone longer term. 
“We need guarantees and we need the government to stop dithering and start to set out how the economy will look as a result of the referendum. It is vital that ministers match our ambition, and I made this clear to Greg Clark when we spoke this week.” 
One candidate for the role of North East mayor argued however that the biggest threat to jobs and investment in the region was Labour’s inactivity over devolution. 
Independent candidate Jeremy Middleton said: “Local Labour politicians are threatening to press the self-destruct button on the region’s economy because they are scared to fight an election. This decision, which could mean the region loses jobs and investment, has been taken because they saw their power-base in the North East threatened in the EU referendum. 
“This is not a time for playing political games. It is more important than ever to make the case that the North East is open for business. However they have sent out the opposite message. While the leaders of Manchester, Liverpool, London, Sheffield and Teesside are championing investment, our politicians are effectively turning it away. 
He added: “What our leaders don’t realise is that following the Brexit vote, the Northern Powerhouse and devolution agenda is more important than ever. The devo-deal would mean real power to change our region for the better, with new budgets to create more jobs and get better skills for our kids, and to improve our transport and NHS.” 
Any agreement over devolution has been postponed until a new prime minister and chancellor are in place.
